## What Remains

**What We Know:**

Between 1847 and 1851, Daniel and Mary Connor McCormick buried three of their children in Dublin: Julia (died 1847, age ~17), Michael (died 1848, age ~12), and Daniel Jr. (died 1851, age ~7). Within four years, during the worst of the Great Famine, they lost a teenager, a child, and a little boy. By July 1852, Daniel Sr. was dead as well. Mary would emigrate to America as a widow in her fifties, leaving behind four graves.

**What We Imagine:**

A worn table. Three pairs of shoes, graduated in sizeâ€”the eldest to the youngest. A slate that will never again hold a child's lessons. A spinning top, stilled. A fragment of lace. A wildflower, wilted but not yet discarded, as if someone still cannot bear to throw it away.

These objects are invention. We have no record of what Julia, Michael, or Daniel owned, wore, or treasured. But we know they existed. We know they died young. And we know that someoneâ€”Mary, certainlyâ€”carried their absence forward across an ocean and into a new life.

The records do not tell us how she grieved. They tell us only that she survived.

This is a good example of **hallucination risk** in action. When AI encounters gaps in provided information, it sometimes "fills in" plausible-sounding details rather than acknowledging uncertainty. Mitigation strategies:

```
When writing about [ancestor], use ONLY the following documented facts: [list specific facts with sources]. Do not infer, extrapolate, or estimate any details not explicitly provided. If information is missing, state "unknown" or "not documented."
```

This constraint-based prompting forces the AI to stay within evidentiary boundsâ€”essential for GPS-compliant work.

## What Remains

**What We Know:**

Between 1847 and 1851, Daniel and Mary Connor McCormick buried three of their children in Dublin, all interred in Goldenbridge Cemetery, Section S8. Julia died on 16 August 1847, age 10. Michael died on 10 August 1849, age 11. Daniel Jr. died on 8 February 1851, age 6. Within four years, during the worst of the Great Famine, they lost three children. By July 1852, Daniel Sr. was dead as well, buried in the same section.

But other children survived. John emigrated first, arriving in Norwich, Connecticut, by the early 1860s. Thomas and Daniel (the younger brother, not the child who died) followed around 1865. Mary Connor McCormick, now a widow in her fifties, came tooâ€”by 1870, she was head of her own household in Norwich, working in a paper mill. The sisters followed: Mary McCormick Young arrived in Quebec in May 1866; Honora McCormick Murphy landed in New York in October 1870; Bridget McCormick Duff, newly widowed herself, arrived in August 1881.

**What We Imagine:**

A worn table. Three pairs of shoes, graduated in sizeâ€”the eleven-year-old's largest, then the ten-year-old's, then the six-year-old's smallest. A slate that will never again hold a child's lessons. A spinning top, stilled. A fragment of lace. A wildflower, wilted but not yet discarded, as if someone still cannot bear to throw it away.

These objects are invention. We have no record of what Julia, Michael, or Daniel owned, wore, or treasured. But we know they existed. We know they died young. We know exactly where they are buried.

And we know this: Mary did not stay to tend those graves. She chose to follow the living. Sometime after 1852, she left Dublinâ€”left Goldenbridge, left Section S8, left her husband and three children in Irish soilâ€”and crossed an ocean to join the sons and daughters who had survived.

The records do not tell us whether she looked back. They tell us only that she went forward.
